author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have read the package naming guidelines: https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment. You can edit blocking comments, adding `[noblock]` to them in order to unblock auto-merging.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

[noblock] now added.

Blocking this for for now so we do not end up with 2 or 3 names. I have nothing against this one with TGV (what does it mean?), and would want it merged eventually if ..Tgv can actually be reverted.

https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/90830#issuecomment-1728439715

@korbinian90 I think what you have to do is to fork/clone the General registry, manually make the changes to the already merged package registration, and then open a pull request. You can’t do this via the Registrator bot (i.e., by registering a new package)

[noblock]

[noblock]

@korbinian90 I unblock here, on my account, since this PR seems harmless after all (and if I'm wrong then ok since I wasn't the only one blocking). @goerz blocked also by responding, so I guess you will have to do similar.

I mainly blocked in the first place to get your attention, e.g. in case you wanted to (only) use the already registered name.

I unblock here, since this is an older PR and thus would go through earlier, in 1 day. It might be best to get a manual intervention still, to drop the other ASAP. This PR doesn't drop any files so it seems like a change to have both package names registered concurrently. There's strictly nothing hugely wrong with that. The registry wouldn't know if these are similar names to completely different packages, or as here linking to same repo (or I doubt that would be considered).

I think if this goes thought then the latest PR would also go through and drop the other name. I see these are strictly not identical, e.g. in the dropped file:

git-tree-sha1 = "31b91ef876942bd473e6000e4b313117861e38ca"

but different in the replacement. I'm not up to speed on this, if right or wrong to change or doesn't matter.

Hypothetically, and I've considered bringing it up officially, instead of renaming, then just adding new official names, and keep the older registered name, maybe with some special marking so it's known it's a synonym. You don't think you have users already, but you wouldn't, maybe couldn't know... It seems harmless if Pkg could install synonyms, for typos even.

It would be best if it would show, e.g. you installed a synonym QuantitativeSusceptibilityMappingTgv, for QuantitativeSusceptibilityMappingTGV and using or import only works for the latter. What do you think of such? I at least we would actively not want using and import respecting both, and without a notification it could be very confusing to install a package and not be able to do using for the copy-pasted name...

@PallHaraldsson Thank you for the explanation!
I would prefer renaming completely and dropping the old name to avoid confusion and make it simpler, since it was registered for less than 2 weeks under the wrong name. In case anyone already started using it in that time, I would think they would have used the install instruction from the README that still mentions the installation with the full URL (not using the Julia Registry).

I created this pull request: https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/91937
It removes the wrong name and adds the new name with the adjusted git commit of my package. Do you think that is fine and can merge it?

[noblock]

@korbinian90 Yes I agree with that other PR.  It doesn't rule out merging this one first (and I only suggested that to speed things along), which is blocked by your and @goerz's comment. I think it gets unblocked, and thus merged immediately aft both of you comment with [unhblock], then the other tomorrow.

[noblock] Maybe I'm just too confused at this point, but I don't think that this PR and #91937 are compatible.

Either *rename* the existing package (which I think #91937 does) and close this PR. Or, merge his PR and make another PR which *deletes* the package with the wrong name (which is different from what #91937 does)

[unblock] ok, if it would be faster, we can let this one go through.
If this one is merged and registers the new name, I would rebase #91937, so it only removes the old package name.
If #91937 would be merged, everything is done and I would close this one.
[noblock] Does `[unblock]` do anything? I thought that every comment has to include exactly the tag `[noblock]`…?

~~Well, given that you posted on Slack, I'm going to block again.~~

[noblock]

[noblock] And just to be absolutely clear about the blocking/unblocking: both @korbinian90 and @PallHaraldsson still have several blocking comments. *Every* comment must be edited to contain `[noblock]` (not `[unblock]` or anything else). You can't unblock the entire PR by just posting another comment containing `[noblock]`/`[unblock]`
Ah, thanks for clarifying! I just assumed from reading that's how it works

[noblock]

I added [noblock] to comments I missed here, and I believe it's enough for the rename, for it to automatically go through if everyone adds that/changes from [unblock] here.

Thank you for noblocking, but it seems like this pull request shouldn't go through as it creates two folders with names only differing by case, which causes problems on Windows and Mac filesystems. 
I posted on slack and maybe there is a solution: https://julialang.slack.com/archives/C6M4DQA5P/p1696401544532679

Otherwise I'll change the name of my package back. Thanks for your input!

body:
- Registering package: QuantitativeSusceptibilityMappingTGV
- Repository: https://github.com/korbinian90/QuantitativeSusceptibilityMappingTGV.jl
- Created by: @korbinian90
- Version: v0.1.0
- Commit: 4f7adfd48a011118ed6a2d85066ffbd82fe22202

- Reference: https://github.com/korbinian90/QuantitativeSusceptibilityMappingTGV.jl/commit/4f7adfd48a011118ed6a2d85066ffbd82fe22202#commitcomment-126459769

title: New package: QuantitativeSusceptibilityMappingTGV v0.1.0
